issue.title: kernel panic when cache is enabled and server responds with tcp segmentation

labels.name: TDB
labels.description: Tempesta DB module and related issues

milestone.title: 0.8 - Beta
milestone.description: TDB v0.2 PoC, HTTP/2 performance. [Beta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_release_life_cycle#Beta) - feature complete, but may have known and unknown bugs.

issue.body:
# Scope
Kernel panic occurs when

- response has body;
- TCP chunk of  server response < 100 bytes;
- cache is enabled;

See #1408 

```python

# Testing
Any test from `cache.test_cache`.

commits.message:
Fix ulimited body parsing

If the response doesn't have body tempesta parses the body until the connection
is closed, in this case need to update overall body size and don't make
chunks.

-Added error handling to `tfw_cache_h2_copy_body()`

Add body iterator

There is copule of places where need to iterate over http message body.
For this purposes has been added body iterator. Just initialize
iterator and chunk using `tfw_body_iter_init()` with error handling.
Use `TFW_BODY_ITER_WALK` macro for walking over the body as TfwStr.

tfw_apm_hm_srv_alive(): Calculate crc32 for message body using body
itertor instead of looping invalid TfwStr.
Remove unused macro

pull_request.title: Fix ulimited body parsing
pull_request.body:
If the response doesn't have body tempesta parses the body until the connection is closed, in this case need to update overall body size and don't make chunks.

-Added error handling to `tfw_cache_h2_copy_body()`

issue.title: h2spec: http2/4.3/3 and http2/6.2/2 - incorrect processing of header block in different streams

milestone.title: 0.8 - Beta
milestone.description: TDB v0.2 PoC, HTTP/2 performance. [Beta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_release_life_cycle#Beta) - feature complete, but may have known and unknown bugs.

issue.body:
# Scope
Tempesta must not process header block (HEADERS, CONTINUATION, PUSH_PROMISE frames) in new streams until it receives END_HEADERS in previous stream.

1. Client send HEADERS frame with stream_id = 1 and END_HEADERS - False;
2. Client send HEADERS frame with stream_id = 3
3. Client send CONTINUATION frame with stream_id = 1 and END_HEADERS - True

ER: GOAWAY frame with PROTOCOL ERROR
AR: Tempesta returns HEADERS frame.

[RFC 9113 4.3](https://httpwg.org/specs/rfc9113.html#FieldBlock)

> Each field block is processed as a discrete unit. Field blocks MUST be transmitted as a contiguous sequence of frames, with no interleaved frames of any other type or from any other stream. The last frame in a sequence of HEADERS or CONTINUATION frames has the END_HEADERS flag set. The last frame in a sequence of PUSH_PROMISE or CONTINUATION frames has the END_HEADERS flag set. This allows a field block to be logically equivalent to a single frame.

# Testing

Tests to reproduce [1](https://github.com/tempesta-tech/tempesta-test/blob/c485d6c32ae365ca10756f2bd3fc14bb3c5eb21a/http2_general/test_h2_specs.py#L110) and [2](https://github.com/tempesta-tech/tempesta-test/blob/c485d6c32ae365ca10756f2bd3fc14bb3c5eb21a/http2_general/test_h2_specs.py#L120). Please enable tests after fix.

comment.body: Also there is a problem with sending responses to clients if we have error in parsing request before we receive END_HEADER flag. We have some problems in processing stream state.

TMP1
TMP

issue.title: WordPress CMS authentication doesn't work over HTTP/2

milestone.title: 0.8 - Beta
milestone.description: TDB v0.2 PoC, HTTP/2 performance. [Beta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_release_life_cycle#Beta) - feature complete, but may have known and unknown bugs.

comment.body:
For some reason, WordPress or Apache send Set-Cookie Header duplicates.
```
$ curl --resolve tempesta-tech.com:443:10.201.210.8 -i -s --insecure 'https://tempesta-tech.com/wp-login.php?redirect_to=https%3A%2F%2Ftempesta-tech.com%2Fwp-admin%2F&reauth=1' | head -n 30
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Wed, 25 Oct 2023 13:26:36 GMT
Server: Apache/2.4.52 (Ubuntu)
Expires: Wed, 11 Jan 1984 05:00:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-cache, must-revalidate, max-age=0
Set-Cookie: wordpress_test_cookie=WP%20Cookie%20check; path=/; secure
X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN
Set-Cookie: wordpress_42fb2087226d3f46392648a70a4cc886=%20; expires=Tue, 25-Oct-2022 13:26:36 GMT; Max-Age=0; path=/wp-admin

issue.title: HTTP/2 Rapid Reset DDoS Mitigaton

milestone.title: 0.8 - Beta
milestone.description: TDB v0.2 PoC, HTTP/2 performance. [Beta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_release_life_cycle#Beta) - feature complete, but may have known and unknown bugs.

issue.body:
# Motivation

Provide protection against HTTP/2 Rapid Reset if TempestaFW is susceptible to this type of attack.

# Links

Original blog post: https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/identity-security/how-it-works-the-novel-http2-rapid-reset-ddos-attack

CVE: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-44487

Possible remediation: https://gist.github.com/adulau/7c2bfb8e9cdbe4b35a5e131c66a0c088#potential-remediation

# Motivation

Provide protection against HTTP/2 Rapid Reset if TempestaFW is susceptible to this type of attack.

# Links

comment.body: We have `request_rate` and ``request_burst` directives from frang against this DDoS-attack. Closed as completed.

issue.title: TLS handshakes traceability

labels.name: TLS
labels.description: Tempesta TLS module and related issues

labels.name: good to start
labels.description: Start form this tasks if you're new in Tempesta FW

milestone.title: 0.8 - Beta
milestone.description: TDB v0.2 PoC, HTTP/2 performance. [Beta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_release_life_cycle#Beta) - feature complete, but may have known and unknown bugs.

issue.body:
Also see https://github.com/tempesta-tech/tempesta/issues/1454 as a parent issue

# Motivation

At the moment I see many TLS errors in the logs for our web site:
```
root@Web:/var/log/vm-logs# tail site-01.log 
[1091003.544952] [tempesta tls] Warning: TLS: server requested by client is not known.
[1091003.549718] [tempesta fw] Warning: Unrecognized TLS receive return code -0x7900, drop packet
[1091075.634226] [tempesta tls] Warning: TLS: server requested by client is not known.
[1091075.638676] [tempesta fw] Warning: Unrecognized TLS receive return code -0x7900, drop packet
[1092296.243290] [tempesta tls] Warning: TLS: server requested by client is not known.
[1092296.247653] [tempesta fw] Warning: Unrecognized TLS receive return code -0x7900, drop packet
[1092346.066903] [tempesta tls] Warning: TLS: server requested by client is not known.
[1092346.071277] [tempesta fw] Warning: Unrecognized TLS receive return code -0x7900, drop packet
[1092442.606719] [tempesta tls] Warning: TLS: server requested by client is not known.
[1092442.611042] [tempesta fw] Warning: Unrecognized TLS receive return code -0x7900, drop packet
```
I'm afraid that live normal clients can't access our website. 

# Scope

There are several points to improve:
- [ ] TLS and Tempesta FW layers must print adequate reason for connection break, `-0x7900` looks not user friendly. I'd propose to use some static table resolving the codes to human readable messages (probably we should return not so large values in such case or just subtract some constant).
- [ ] we should report the error only once, not twice on FW and TLS layers as in the log above
- [x] `/proc/tempesta/perfstat` must show numbers of successful and and failed TLS handshakes 


# Testing & documentation

No need any specific documentation or tests.

comment.body:
I still observe poor TLS error codes in the log, like
```
[12749.342064] [tempesta tls] Warning: [::ffff:167.248.133.49] Bad TLS record (err -0xFFFFF003)
```
It'd be good at least to understand on which TLS phase this happens (in the middle of a connection or somewhere in a handshake or even a ClientHello) and what exactly is wrong with the record. If we can realize from the message that for example we don't support some ciphersuite, then that would help a lot.

commits.message:
Rework socket closing

There was a problem in our closing procedure. When we
close connection with TCP FIN we immediately mark socket
as DEAD and do not wait until FIN and all remaining data
will be sent. (Usual tcp_close() call sk_stream_wait_close()
to wait until it will be nothing to send). If remote peer
sends some data to us after we mark socket as DEAD TCP code
answer with TCP RST, that could lead to loosing some unsend
data.
To solve this problem clsing procedure was splitted into two
part. In first part we send TCP FIN and return. Then we wait
for ACK to our FIN from remote peer and finish closing.

Implement handling of HTTP2_PRIORITY frames for idle streams

HTTP2_PRIORITY frames are allowed for the idle streams. Moreover
some clients use this ability to set weight and dependency for
idle stream, so we should handle HTTP2_PRIORITY for such streams.

Implement stream prioritization according RFC 7540

Implement stream scheduler to have ability to get
the most priority stream. HTTP2 connection context
contains stream scheduler and each stream also
contains scheduler for its children, so we have a
tree of schedulers. Each scheduler contains array
of 64 list heads for the streams and bitfield to
find most priority stream.
In this commit we implement scheduler strategy based
on h2o scheduler, but after discussion we decide to
rework it later.

Add check for schedulers functions

Add check that all schedulers functions are
called under the socket lock.

Implement `max_concurrent_streams` limitation

According to RFC 7540, server should limit count of
active streams per connection for security reasons.
SETTINGS_MAX_CONCURRENT_STREAMS settings parameter
is used for this purpose. Implement new Tempesta FW
configuration parameter `max_concurrent_streams`
(with default value 200), which is used to limit
count of active and idle (for which a priority frame
was sent) streams per connection according RFC 7540.
We take into account such idle streams because we
allocate memory for them.

Implement "latency_optimized_write" option

By default we use delayed queuing of skbs to
socket write queue, that allows higher priority
data to be placed ahead of lower priority data.
Setting "latency_optimized_write" option to
"false" disable this behaviour.

Remove hpack table spin lock and guard

Since all hpack encoding was moved to the 'tcp_write_xmit'
function we don't need any additional locks, since 'tcp_write_xmit'
is always called under the socket lock.

Fix several bugs in previous commits

- When we send request to the client we increment
  reference counter to the connection and we should
  release the connection only when we release appropriate
  responce
- We encode headers and cutoff body chunks in the
  xmit callback, so there can be some empty skbs after such
  process. We should not send them to socket write queue.
- We should release response and put the connection when
  we stop stream if there are response for xmit to this
  stream.

Fix assetion in the `tfw_http_conn_drop`

Dropping connection should be called under
the socket lock.

Fixes to previous commits and improvements

- Implement several functions for some code,
  which is used in several places.
- We should immediately delete response if we
  can't send it.
- Do not forget to release response and connection
  in case of errors.
- Implement special state to release response in
  xmit callback.

Fix `tfw_h2_closed_streams_shrink` function.

We chould shrink closed streams if count
of closed streams is equal to max streams.

Do not break making headers because of exceeding CWND.

We should not break making headers because of exceeding CWND, since
there is a chance that some other frames (for example ack to settings
will be sent between sending headers.

Move applying of new settings to `ss_do_send`

New settings should be applyed just before ack to
this settings is pushed to the socket write queue,
because otherwise new settings can be applyed and
some frames with this new settings will be sent
before ack to this settings.

Port ebtree to tempesta

According to our investigation ebtree is the fastest
data structure for stream prioritization, so we should
port it to our project.
Rework streams scheduler algorithm.

Remove unnecessary functions from ebtree

We dont need all functions from ported ebtree.

Rework streams scheduler allocation

- Decrease default value of max concurrent streams to 100
- Move checking that all schedulers functions are called
  under the socket lock to the http_stream_sched.* file.
- Add array of 100 child schedulers to the main connection
  schedulers. Now stream doesn't contain scheduler itself,
  only pointer to the scheduler. If max concurrent streams
  is less or equal 100, get stream schedulers from the array
  otherwise allocate necessary count of additional pages for
  the stream schedulers.

Fix according review

- Change T_FSM_NEXT to direct jump to appropriate state.
- Adjust cwnd after making headers or continuation frames
  first time.
- Codestyle fixes.
- Rework calculation of awailable cwnd, now we get into
  account current length of socket write queue.
Remove holes from structures.
Add comments according review

pull_request.title: Fix incorrect processing of request method by frang
pull_request.body:
When we send request with TCP SEGMENTATION, we call frang on each parsed byte. But when we parse request method we set it value to _TFW_HTTP_METH_UNKNOWN,
before we finish parsing request method. Implement additional value for request method, to mark that
we not fully parse request method and do not process such method value by frang.

Closes #1872

repo.name: tempesta
repo.description: All-in-one solution for high performance web content delivery and advanced protection against DDoS and web attacks

commits.message:
Fix incorrect processing of request method by frang

When we send request with TCP SEGMENTATION, we call
frang on each parsed byte. But when we parse request
method we set it value to _TFW_HTTP_METH_UNKNOWN,
before we finish parsing request method. Implement
additional value for request method, to mark that
we not fully parse request method and do not process
such method value by frang.

Closes #1872

comment.body: `_TFW_HTTP_METH_INCOMPLETE` might be a better name for this purpose.
